p.s: At first Starr is really insecure about the situation she finds herself in.
She wasn't back at the place where Khalil died since it happened so she sees all the images again in her mind.
This scene gets compared to a horror movie by herself to demonstrate how scared she is or was (ll. 5-6).
She then snaps out of her vision and sees Ms. Ofrah and the crowd chanting.
This encourages her to chant aswell.
She sees the death scene again while shouting but it encourages her to chant louder.
By recruiting Khalil's death the reader imagines and remembers the scene again and can feel the encouragement and power Starr gets from this.
By creating a rhythm between Starr's shouts and the scene the reader emphasizesempathizes with the situation Starr is in and Starr herself (ll. 18-23).
After she feels confident she went on top of a police car and tries to use her weapon, which is a comparison by Ms. Ofrah and really means her voice.
She stutters but the crowd tells her to speak.
In the who passage the crowd and Ms. Ofrah amps her up by chanting to her.
This is presented by many exclamations, which do make sense because it is an event of protest in which thsi scene does take place (ll. 40, 45-46, 51).
Near the end she starts to like it.
This can be seen by her thinking more cheers, ..., it eggs on me (l. 57).
If you comparcompare this to the start a large gain of confidence can be seen which was made possible because of Ms. Ofrah and the crowd.
At the end she shouts His life mattered.Khalil lived! which could resemble Black Lives Matter or could be inspired from it.
